info.game_comments: 2005 Ultimate Tournament of Champions Round 2, game 3.

(1, 1).clue: If you're tall & tan & young & lovely, head to Ipanema Beach in this city

(2, 1).clue: This Queen of Soul is No. 1 on VH1's list of the 100 Greatest Women of Rock & Roll

(4, 1).clue: These items, occasionally sold by an unnamed woman by the seashore, "make good soap dishes"

(5, 1).clue: Born in Cambridge in 1921, he went on to be a senator & an astronaut

(6, 1).clue: The National Enquirer or The Weekly World News, for example

(1, 2).clue: Vikings founded the first permanent settlement in this national capital around 874

(2, 2).clue: She's the angelic-voiced singer from Canada heard here"In the arms of the angels..."

(4, 2).clue: "Take off flight tags to avoid confusion about your destination" to prevent losing this (& your mind)

(5, 2).clue: Born in Darke County in 1860, she developed her amazing proficiency with firearms at an early age

(6, 2).clue: This name of this muscle that covers the  shoulder joint tells you that it's triangular

(1, 3).clue: Give me this state capital where the "Give me liberty or give me death" speech was delivered

(2, 3).clue: She first joined 10,000 Maniacs when she was 17 and still in college

(4, 3).clue: Repotting this warm-weather plant "can be a sticky situation unless you have... carpet scraps to handle" it

(5, 3).clue: Appropriately enough, this writer of Westerns was born in Zanesville in 1872

(6, 3).clue: A Domino's Pizza ad campaign said to "avoid" this mascot

(1, 4).clue: Founded in the 13th century, this major Dutch port was heavily damaged by German bombing in World War II

(2, 4).clue: During the disco era, teacher Anita Ward chimed in with this No. 1 hit

(3, 4).clue: ...among the books of the Old Testament

(4, 4).clue: In summer "when nobody nice can help you", use a "sponge-type... mop" with a long handle to apply this to your back

(5, 4).clue: Born in Columbus in 1890, he was a car-racing champion & a WWI flying ace

(6, 4).clue: Mary Mallon was famously a carrier of this fever

(1, 5).clue: Situated on the road to Mecca, it became the seat of the Saud dynasty around 1824

(2, 5).clue: Her 1992 hit "I Can't Make You Love Me" features Bruce Hornsby on piano

(4, 5).clue: After pinching off its "green hat", slice this fruit with an egg slicer; "no stains on your fingers"

(5, 5).clue: This late jazz pianist, famous for his trio, was born blind in Toledo, Ohio in 1910

(6, 5).clue: Alexander Parkes developed this synthetic plastic material in 1856

(1, 1).clue: (Jeff Probst reports from Vanuatu.)  The largest of Vanuatu's more than 80 islands, Espiritu Santo is Spanish for this member of the Trinity

(2, 1).clue: Tim played inmate number 37927 in this 1994 film

(3, 1).clue: He left home in 1206 to devote himself to caring for the lepers & rebuilding churches in & around Assisi

(4, 1).clue: One of the largest herds of these animals in the U.S. is found at South Dakota's Custer State Park

(5, 1).clue: In 1997 this television network's president called Exxon Mobil "our corporate Medici"

(1, 2).clue: Vanuatu's capital, this "port" sounds like it's named for the former host of "This Old House"

(2, 2).clue: This title Robbins character runs for Senate against a liberal incumbent played by Gore Vidal

(3, 2).clue: Japan's emperor was worshipped as a descendant of Amaterasu-Omikami, this religion's sun goddess

(4, 2).clue: Basil Fawlty asked a guest unhappy with the view if she'd expected to see "herds of" these "sweeping majestically..."

(5, 2).clue: Putting its name on Columbus' arena, this company insured that Ohioans would know it's "on your side"

(6, 2).clue: Shared historic nickname of the San Francisco waterfront & the North African shore

(1, 3).clue: A WWII liner named for this "silent" president is one of the world's largest intact scuba-accessible shipwrecks

(2, 3).clue: Tim also felt the need for speed as Merlin in this 1986 blockbuster flick

(3, 3).clue: Construction on Borobudur, a temple of this religion on Java, was begun in 750 A.D. & took 92 years to complete

(4, 3).clue: This organization, the AKC, classifies sheepdogs as a herding breed

(6, 3).clue: While cats have whiskers, catfish have whiskerlke feelers called these

(1, 4).clue: This type of "cult" believes that a pilot named John Frum will arrive some day bearing a wealth of consumer goods

(2, 4).clue: Tim gets some valuable advice from a teammate in this film: "Don't think. It can only hurt the ball club"

(3, 4).clue: Hindu traditions say the creator god Brahma emerged from this, which grows from the navel of Vishnu

(4, 4).clue: For centuries, reindeer herding was the main economy of these people of Northern Scandinavia

(5, 4).clue: Aptly, this Kellogg's product has sponsored the "American Idol" live tour

(1, 5).clue: (Jeff Probst reports from Vanuatu.)  In colonial times, Britain & France ruled Vanuatu in a joint arrangement known as this; locals just called it pandemonium

(2, 5).clue: Tim jumped through (hula) hoops in this '94 Coen Brothers flick with Paul Newman

(3, 5).clue: The Talmud consists of the Mishnah, the written version of Jewish oral law, & this, commentary on the Mishnah

(6, 5).clue: Mid-19th century "school" of French painters that included Millet

(0, 0).clue: When his tomb was opened in 1102, a fragrance filled the air, & his body was perfectly preserved
